Award.AwardTitle: Periods and special values of L-functions for unitary groups
Award.AbstractNarration:
The study of L-functions or zeta functions has a long history in mathematics, dating back to Gauss, Riemann, Dirichlet, Hecke, Artin, et al. In the last fifty years, lots of progress has been made after Langlands introduced the deep philosophy between number theory and automorphic forms. Among these, the relation between special values of L-functions and periods, which the PI proposes to study, is one of the most important problems. Precisely, the first part of the proposal is about the global restriction problems of automorphic representations in the framework of the Gan-Gross-Prasad conjecture. With various collaborators, the PI will formulate an explicit conjecture for those periods, generalizing the work of Ichino-Ikeda, as well as study the case of unitary groups using the tool of relative trace formula, proposed by Jacquet-Rallis in a special case and the PI in general. The second part of the proposal is to understand the relation between central derivatives of L-functions and certain arithmetic periods, namely, height of cycles on Shimura varieties. The PI proposes to study such relation via arithmetic theta lifting after Kudla and the PI himself, in particular, in the next unknown case of U(2,2).

The ultimate goal of this research is to better understand one of the central questions in mathematics: how to solve equations, particularly, algebraic equations in number fields. These equations hide themselves in various kinds of mathematical objects, such as algebraic cycles, representations, period relations, etc. The Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture is one of the most famous questions toward this direction. Outside pure mathematics, algebraic equations like elliptic curves, have important application in cryptography.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of the award are listed as follows.


1. In the paper with the title Refined Gan-Gross-Prasad conjecture for Bessel periods, to be published in Journal fur die reine und angewandte Mathematik, the PI formulated a refined version of the global Gan-Gross-Prasad conjecture for general Bessel periods. The conjecture is an explicit formula relating certain automorphic periods and L-functions. Note that L-functions are among the most important objects in the study of modern number theory. Moreover, the PI obtained some new examples of such refined formula as evidence toward the conjecture.


2. In the paper with the title Hirzebruch-Zagier cycles and twisted triple product Selmer groups, published in Inventiones Mathematicae (vol. 205), the PI studies the so-called Bloch-Kato conjecture, which is a vast generalization of the famous Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer (B-SD) conjecture. Such conjecture roughly predicts that the order of the L-function at the central point is equal to the dimension of an arithmetic invariant, known as the Bloch-Kato Selmer group. In this paper, the PI studies such conjecture for a motive of rank eight, which replaces the role of the elliptic curve in B-SD conjecture, and obtains important results toward the Bloch-Kato conjecture in the case that the L-function has order at most 1.


3. In the preprint with the title Bounding cubic-triple product Selmer groups of elliptic curves, the PI continues to study the Bloch-Kato conjecture in the previous paper. This time, the motive is more complicated and there are new difficulties in the original approach. To overcome, the PI developed certain new techniques, which is hopeful to be generalized to higher dimensions as well.


4. The PI finished a long-term project with the collaborator Weizhe Zheng at Chinese Academy of Science partially under the support of the award with three preprints, with titles Gluing restricted nerves of infinity categories, Enhanced six operations and base change theorem for Artin stacks, and Enhanced adic formalism and perverse t-structures for higher Artin stacks. In these papers, we develop a new theory of Grothendieck's six operations for Artin stacks. This theory is very important in the study of etale cohomology of schemes or more generally stacks; it has fundamental applications to many problems in both algebraic geometry and number theory. Our approach is new, in the sense that we study natural enhancement of the category of etale sheaves, using the advanced theory of infinity categories. Our method already inspires some other works in the field.


5. In the most recent preprint with the title Weight decomposition of de Rham cohomology sheaves and tropical cycle classes for non-Archimedean spaces, the PI studies some questions in the potential theory of non-Archimedean analytic spaces. More precisely, the PI established certain fundamental results in the de Rham theory of such spaces in both algebraic sense and analytic sense. The angle of such research is very new, and is expected to shed further light in the field. In particular, the methods and the results may have further applications to Arakelov geometry, an important tool in the study of number theory.


All of the above research outcomes address the intellectual merits mentioned in the award proposal, and actually go beyond. For example, the research on the Bloch-Kato conjecture is a substantial addition to the intellectual merits. The first paper on Gan-Gross-Prasad generated a problem, which was later solved as part of the PhD thesis of some other mathematician in the field. This contributes to the broader impart of the award.
